t: Luke 19
Zacchaeus the Tax Collector
Jesus*p entered Jericho and was passing through.
A man was there by the name of Zacchaeus; he was a chief tax collector and was wealthy.
He wanted to see who Jesus was, but because he was short he could not see over the crowd.
So he ran ahead and climbed a sycamore-fig tree to see him, since Jesus was coming that way.
When*p Jesus reached the spot, he looked up and said to him, “Zacchaeus,*r come*r down*r immediately.*r I*r must*r stay*r at*r your*r house*r today.”*r
So he came down at once and welcomed him gladly.
All*p the people saw this and began to mutter, “He has gone to be the guest of a sinner.”

But*p Zacchaeus stood up and said to the Lord, “Look, Lord! Here and now I give half of my possessions to the poor, and if I have cheated anybody out of anything, I will pay back four times the amount.”
Jesus*p said to him, “Today*r salvation*r has*r come*r to*r this*r house,*r because*r this*r man,*r too,*r is*r a*r son*r of*r Abraham.*r
For*r the*r Son*r of*r Man*r came*r to*r seek*r and*r to*r save*r the*r lost.”*r
The Parable of the Ten Minas
While*p they were listening to this, he went on to tell them a parable, because he was near Jerusalem and the people thought that the kingdom of God was going to appear at once.
He said: “A*r man*r of*r noble*r birth*r went*r to*r a*r distant*r country*r to*r have*r himself*r appointed*r king*r and*r then*r to*r return.*r
So*r he*r called*r ten*r of*r his*r servants*r and*r gave*r them*r ten*r minas.*r ‘Put*r this*r money*r to*r work,’*r he*r said,*r ‘until*r I*r come*r back.’*r
“But*rp his*r subjects*r hated*r him*r and*r sent*r a*r delegation*r after*r him*r to*r say,*r ‘We*r don’t*r want*r this*r man*r to*r be*r our*r king.’*r

“He*rp was*r made*r king,*r however,*r and*r returned*r home.*r Then*r he*r sent*r for*r the*r servants*r to*r whom*r he*r had*r given*r the*r money,*r in*r order*r to*r find*r out*r what*r they*r had*r gained*r with*r it.*r
“The*rp first*r one*r came*r and*r said,*r ‘Sir,*r your*r mina*r has*r earned*r ten*r more.’*r
“ ‘Well*rp done,*r my*r good*r servant!’*r his*r master*r replied.*r ‘Because*r you*r have*r been*r trustworthy*r in*r a*r very*r small*r matter,*r take*r charge*r of*r ten*r cities.’*r
“The*rp second*r came*r and*r said,*r ‘Sir,*r your*r mina*r has*r earned*r five*r more.’*r
“His*rp master*r answered,*r ‘You*r take*r charge*r of*r five*r cities.’*r
“Then*rp another*r servant*r came*r and*r said,*r ‘Sir,*r here*r is*r your*r mina;*r I*r have*r kept*r it*r laid*r away*r in*r a*r piece*r of*r cloth.*r
I*r was*r afraid*r of*r you,*r because*r you*r are*r a*r hard*r man.*r You*r take*r out*r what*r you*r did*r not*r put*r in*r and*r reap*r what*r you*r did*r not*r sow.’*r

“His*rp master*r replied,*r ‘I*r will*r judge*r you*r by*r your*r own*r words,*r you*r wicked*r servant!*r You*r knew,*r did*r you,*r that*r I*r am*r a*r hard*r man,*r taking*r out*r what*r I*r did*r not*r put*r in,*r and*r reaping*r what*r I*r did*r not*r sow?*r
Why*r then*r didn’t*r you*r put*r my*r money*r on*r deposit,*r so*r that*r when*r I*r came*r back,*r I*r could*r have*r collected*r it*r with*r interest?’*r
“Then*rp he*r said*r to*r those*r standing*r by,*r ‘Take*r his*r mina*r away*r from*r him*r and*r give*r it*r to*r the*r one*r who*r has*r ten*r minas.’*r
“ ‘Sir,’*rp they*r said,*r ‘he*r already*r has*r ten!’*r

“He*rp replied,*r ‘I*r tell*r you*r that*r to*r everyone*r who*r has,*r more*r will*r be*r given,*r but*r as*r for*r the*r one*r who*r has*r nothing,*r even*r what*r they*r have*r will*r be*r taken*r away.*r
But*r those*r enemies*r of*r mine*r who*r did*r not*r want*r me*r to*r be*r king*r over*r them—bring*r them*r here*r and*r kill*r them*r in*r front*r of*r me.’ ”*r
Jesus Comes to Jerusalem as King
After*p Jesus had said this, he went on ahead, going up to Jerusalem.
As he approached Bethphage and Bethany at the hill called the Mount of Olives, he sent two of his disciples, saying to them,

“Go*r to*r the*r village*r ahead*r of*r you,*r and*r as*r you*r enter*r it,*r you*r will*r find*r a*r colt*r tied*r there,*r which*r no*r one*r has*r ever*r ridden.*r Untie*r it*r and*r bring*r it*r here.*r
If*r anyone*r asks*r you,*r ‘Why*r are*r you*r untying*r it?’*r say,*r ‘The*r Lord*r needs*r it.’ ”*r
Those*p who were sent ahead went and found it just as he had told them.
As they were untying the colt, its owners asked them, “Why are you untying the colt?”
They*p replied, “The Lord needs it.”
They*p brought it to Jesus, threw their cloaks on the colt and put Jesus on it.
As he went along, people spread their cloaks on the road.
When*p he came near the place where the road goes down the Mount of Olives, the whole crowd of disciples began joyfully to praise God in loud voices for all the miracles they had seen:
“Blessed*pn is the king who comes in the name of the Lord!” “Peace*pn in heaven and glory in the highest!”
Some*p of the Pharisees in the crowd said to Jesus, “Teacher, rebuke your disciples!”
“I*rp tell*r you,”*r he replied, “if*r they*r keep*r quiet,*r the*r stones*r will*r cry*r out.”*r
As*p he approached Jerusalem and saw the city, he wept over it
and said, “If*r you,*r even*r you,*r had*r only*r known*r on*r this*r day*r what*r would*r bring*r you*r peace—but*r now*r it*r is*r hidden*r from*r your*r eyes.*r
The*r days*r will*r come*r upon*r you*r when*r your*r enemies*r will*r build*r an*r embankment*r against*r you*r and*r encircle*r you*r and*r hem*r you*r in*r on*r every*r side.*r

They*r will*r dash*r you*r to*r the*r ground,*r you*r and*r the*r children*r within*r your*r walls.*r They*r will*r not*r leave*r one*r stone*r on*r another,*r because*r you*r did*r not*r recognize*r the*r time*r of*r God’s*r coming*r to*r you.”*r
Jesus at the Temple
When*p Jesus entered the temple courts, he began to drive out those who were selling.
“It*r is*r written,”*r he said to them, “ ‘My*r house*r will*r be*r a*r house*r of*r prayer’;*r but*r you*r have*r made*r it*r ‘a*r den*r of*r robbers.’”*r
Every*p day he was teaching at the temple. But the chief priests, the teachers of the law and the leaders among the people were trying to kill him.
Yet they could not find any way to do it, because all the people hung on his words.
